item.title: Microcontrollers & 3D Graphics
item.description:
In this micro project, the objective is to utilize a microcontroller paired with a display to render a rotating 3D cube and evaluate its performance capabilities.

Hardware

Arduino Nano

The Arduino Nano is a small board that uses the 328P microcontroller, offering IO ports (digital in/out (0-5V), analog in/out (ADC, PWM), Serial, I2C, SPI), voltage regulator (LM1117, 7-12V in), and USB communication thru the CH340 chip and a Mini-B usb port.

item.title: Weather Station
item.description:
Given my sudden interest in exploring the potential of microcontrollers, I had to find a new project to try building. So here we are, this time I decided to build a simple weather station with a display to show customizated information.

Product Specs

Let’s define a few product specs to keep the project well scoped:

  • Be able to display temperature in Celsius/Fahrenheit, humidity in %, and pressure in hPa.
  • Be able to navigate thru pages using a physical button.
  • Each page should organize the data in a different way to test different layouts.
  • Be able to keep track of the 100 last samples for a specific time period (second, minute, hour, 3-hour, 8-hour, 24-hour).
  • Keep min and max value of each metric (temperature, humidity, pressure) for each time period.
  • Render a simple chart of the last N samples for a specific time period.
  • Display the amout of time since the last reset.
  • Display the current page number.

Hardware

Microcontroller

I will be using the HiLetgo ESP-32D Development Board. It is a development board that comes with a ESP32-D0WD-V3 microcontroller, serial communication over USB, a voltage regulator, 38 pins (which supports GPIO, I2C, SPI, etc.) and a few other components.

About the content of posts

The “posts” section is a growing collection of notes on a variety of random topics I’m exploring. It might sound a bit confusing, as this isn’t exactly a portfolio to showcase my professional skills, nor is it a personal blog. I think the real reason behind it is that I’m practicing writing and creation of public content. So any topic I find out interesting can be a potential new post.

item.title: Hugo HTML Canvas Support
item.description:
If you need to add HTML canvas or import JavaScript libraries from a CDN in your Hugo website, this post will walk you thru on how to do that.

In the end you will be able to use HTML canvas to render things like a 3d rotating cube from your markdown file:

Hugo Shortcodes

This is possible using Hugo shortcodes. Which is a way to add custom HTML elements to your website like image, video, and HTML canvas. The shortcode is a template invoked within markup, accepting any number of arguments.

item.title: Hugo TeX Support
item.description:
We can use the Katex library to enable Tex support to your hugo website. KaTeX supports all major browsers.

$$ \Huge TeX $$

Installing

Creating a Hugo partial

To install, we just need to import the library files from some CDN to our Hugo website. One way to do this is using the Hugo partials which as small HTML templates that we can import to our website.

To start, lets create a new partial template file to hold the code needed to add the library. Create a new partial file in hugo_root/layouts/tex.html.

item.title: North Cascades National Park
item.description:
The North Cascades are a rugged mountainous region in the northern part of Washington State. It is the northernmost section of the Cascade Range. It features beautiful sharp granite spires, glaciers, deep valleys, and dense conifer forests.

The North Cascades National Park was established on October 2, 1968.

In geology, spires are tall, narrow, pointed rock formations usually the result of erosion and glacial carving acting on hard bedrock.

Location

North Cascades National Park is located in northern Washington state, in the United States. It spans Whatcom, Skagit, and Chelan counties and lies about 100 miles northeast of Seattle, near the Canadian border.

item.title: Rotating Points
item.description:
When playing with 2d/3d computer graphics, image processing, computer vision,etc we often need use the rotation matrix to rotate a point <x,y> or <x,y,z> around origin or around an arbitrary point.

For example, on the following animation, we need to compute the new x’ and y’ of the endpoint of the blue vector. On every frame, we increase the angle by 0.05 rads and compute the new x,y values.

To do that, we use the standard point rotation formula, which is commonly stated as that if you have a point (x, y) and you want rotate by \( \theta \).
